ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of differential geometry, including the definition and uses of Frenet-Serret frame for space curves, the definition of a manifold, the basics of differential forms, the covariant derivative, the Levi-Civita connection, and generalized Stokes' theorem.
I learned some differential geometry: coordinate charts, surfaces, curvature, geodesics, etc....  I also learned about differential forms.  We worked mostly in 3D.
Differential geometry of curves and surfaces in R3, some differential forms and applications to Gauss-Bonnet theorem.

I feel like this course was a great introduction to differential geometry. We first studied curves in the plane, and introduced the concept of curvature. Then we looked at curves in space, and used the Frenet-Serret apparatus to talk about their curvature and torsion. Then we looked at surfaces in space, and we talked about normal and Gauss curvatures. We then introduced differential forms and Stokes' theorem. I would say the "main result" of the course was Gauss's Theorema Egregium.
Differential geometry in mainly 2 and 3 dimensions
Geometry of curves and sufaces, tangent spaces, covariant derivative, shape tensor, curvature, geodesics, differential forms, connection forms, cartan equations
Learned to use derivatives to talk about local properties of manifolds and used this to study global features. Learned the structure given by smoothness.

I learned a ton about differential geometry! The course mostly focused on notions of curvature for curves and surfaces, but we also discussed geodesics, differential forms, de Rham cohomology, Levi-Civita connection, parallel transport, generalized Stokes' theorem, manifolds in A^n, etc.
I learned about differentiation and integration on curves and surfaces, geodesics, Gaussian curvature, etc.
Basic definitions and foundational theorems of differential geometry
How to think about curved shapes
I learned a lot about problem solving in a new field, especially with regards to proofs and understanding of geometry in 3d.
Learned about some of the foundations of differential geometry.
I learned the basics of differential geometry.

I gained some basic foundational knowledge in differential geometry, including exterior products, curvature definitions, examples of interesting surfaces, and many tools that can be applied to other interesting problems. The problem sets allowed us to make calculations about geometric properties of surfaces and made us comfortable with analytical proofs as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The main strengths of this course are that the material is engaging, the pacing is in the Goldilocks zone of not too fast and not too slow, and the course also includes useful information about the applications of the material. Another strength of this course is that it has a final project instead of a final exam, which gave me an opportunity to do a deep dive into a topic which I though was interesting. The main weakness of this course is that at times, it can feel like the course material changes on the whim of the professor, although this could be a strength for a certain type of student.

I liked that we had all the lecture notes compiled into one master document.  Lectures were clear and relatively engaging.  I thought the take-hom midterm worked well, and I like the freedom to choose an individual final project.

I thought the course was taught very well. The lectures were clear and organized. My only complaint is that I wish we did more stuff with manifolds in n dimensions rather than working with surfaces in 3 dimensions all the time. I also kind of wish there were more proofs in the homework assignments.

Sometimes the homework was a little bit boring, but thats about it - I wish there was more theory building in the homework.

The class is fun and the lectures were clear.

This class was fantastic. Prof. Neitzke did a fantastic job of approaching the material from just the right level of abstraction. We didn't ever get too caught up in the weeds, but I always felt like I could sit down and write rigorous proofs if I wanted to. Ever result felt well justified, but managed to avoid the nitty gritty ugly stuff most of the time. The problem sets were great, and they definitely reinforced the concepts from the lectures very well.

The one thing that I will say is that the problem sets tended to be very computation-heavy and were a lot lighter on the proofs. I would have enjoyed having some more substantial proofs in the homework from time to time. 

There was one problem set that I have to mention, because I enjoyed it so much. Prof. Neitzke basically just said "remember that theorem we proved in class? generalize it and provide some sort of justification." That one was a lot of fun, because we could just take it and run with it. The final project was also a lot of fun, for similar reasons. It was very open ended, and gave us a lot of freedom to explore what ever subject we wanted to.

Strengths: diverse topics, accessible, makes reading further diff geo papers easy. Final project was fun.

Weaknesses: frequency of psets wasnt really enough to solidify the content sometimes. It was nice not to have to prove everything, but at some points I felt that a bit more rigor might be helpful, especially when it came to differential forms and connections
Lectures in the course were difficult but informative. I wish there had been more problem set questions to practice the material as well as more proofs in lecture.

This course was excellent. It was not super work heavy, but the problem sets were interesting, and very engaging. The midterm exam was difficult but doable, and the final paper was a fun chance to explore math writing and research.

I thought the lectures were very good, and enjoyed the level of organization of the course (e.g. having lecture notes LaTeXed and updated after every lecture). A weakness was that I didn't always feel like I knew where the class was going, or how different topics tied together, but this might have just been due to my lack of experience with the subject.
Strengths: great lectures, interesting content, fast responses to questions
I think it was really good. At times lecture was a bit confusing or got off track but mostly the material was engaging and the lecture was relatively easy to follow.
Course covered a fairly wide range of topics. thought it could be a little better if it went through more detailed proofs on some particular topics; might be better to emphasize depth over breadth
The course was well-organized and the content was interesting. I think slightly more examples could be given, especially for more difficult concepts, to provide more intuition.

I thought the course was very well organized and intuitive to follow with each concept. The course notes made everything accessible and easy to refer to when following along in lecture, and provided clear annotations of notation and examples that were relevant to the discussion. I thought the course could be improved if we integrated some component of mathematical software, since differential geometry is particularly interesting with the different surfaces you can generate from equations.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course in person lecturing and office hours are better, but it wasn't too bad.
I thought Professor Neitzke's use of the digital lecture format was one of the best I've seen so far. His board work is great and full of sketches which really helped me as a visual learner.
Very good! No problems whatsoever.
Virtual engagement was good!
The course was well-adapted to the pandemic.
I though the course adapted well to the pandemic, and that lectures were always engaging and helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Somehow, the ability to visualize theorems on curves and surfaces makes learning the material way more fun than in a typical math class. If you are a physics student, this course will give you a great formal background for understanding general relativity (we touched on the Levita-Civita connection and the Ricci curvature towards the end of the course).

I would.  It's a good introduction to a cool topic, and the prof is good.  It's not strictly required for the math major, but its a good elective, and it also may help students who are interested in physics and other adjacent fields.
Yes, if youve never seen the material before.
Definitely would recommend. Great professor, interesting material, not too hard. Checks all of the boxes for me :)
Sure. Good upper level math class with a low-medium amount of work and an interesting topic.
I think the material has a lot of potential but the presentation was just ok

Overall yes. Its a little different than other math courses I have taken in that it is a lot less proof-based/rigorous,  but it is a nice change of pace. The workload isnt too intense, and the final project is fun.
This course would benefit from more proofs but the materials is really cool.
Absolutely -- anyone interested in math should totally take this course.
Yes! Nietzke is so compassionate and a fantastic lecturer. Would take another class with him in a heartbeat!
I would recommend this course to anyone who loves mathematics
Yes! I think it was a lot of fun and I learned a lot about the topic.
Would recommend if they are interested in a survey of geometry -- this course doesn't go too in depth with detailed proofs, instead it gives you a feel of what you can study in the field.
Yes, it was a fun and interesting course, challenging enough to be engaging, but not so much that it consumed my semester.
Yes

Definitely. The course may seem intimidating with the dense notation and complicated names of theorems, but it can be intuitive at times and very engaging to follow. The field is very deep, and this course provides an introduction to a lot of the principles needed to explore it further. For anybody interested in geometry and extensions of geometry in graduate-level classes, this would be a perfect fit. We even have the opportunity to explore a topic of our choosing as a final project.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The live lecture was recorded as well.
Professor Neitzke always made sure to ask many questions to keep us engage. It felt like a discussion.
None
Lectures were recorded and could be watched asynchronously as well.
I attended live virtual lectures, and followed along with the course notes.
